abstract.title: About This Video Text
abstract.p: This video text consists of an introduction to Vector Calculus, and is the first ~1/3 of the course Math 204 at the University of Victoria. The remaining ~2/3 of that course is on Ordinary Differential Equations and the videos for that section are in this ODE textbook adapted for Math 204.

I call it a "video book" because it primarily consists of a series of videos. These videos comprised the bulk of an asynchronous online course taught in Spring 2021. Surrounding the videos are Learning Objectives, text summaries, pre- and post-video exercises, and other resources. That is, this video text goes beyond just the playlist on YouTube by providing these additional supports that help scaffold the videos themselves. This is particularly important given my general view that learning mathematics is something best done when you are actively DOING mathematics, and not just passively watching videos.
This project is open-source and the code is available at my github.
If you prefer just the videos, the playlist of all videos from both this book and the ODE book in order is below

Notes about YouTube: Videos in this playlist are not monetized and contain no calls-to-action (ex: "Like and Subscribe"). However, YouTube will unfortunately nevertheless play ads on unmonetized videos occasionally. I additionally and separately have a large public YouTube channel that contains most of the same videos, but those videos often will have calls-to-action in them. It is thus recomended that any UVic student use the version of the videos linked in this video textbook.

colophon.title: Overview of Vector Calculus
colophon.p: In this video I do an overview of the major ideas from Vector Calculus. The goal is to give a bit of perspective of where we are going and gain some broad familiarity with the subject before we actually start doing everything slowly in the subsequent videos.

Post Video Exericses: After most videos in this text, I will give prompts for "Post-Video Activities" that might be practice problems or other activities to help solidfy your understanding. As this first video is an overview, I will simply ask:

li.p: What did you notice?
What did you wonder?

introduction.p: This section is all about our first new object of study, called a line integral

section.title: Review of Curves and Parameterizations
section.p: This video is a review of several concepts we've seen in multivariable calculus, so read the list below and if you're 100% confident you can skip it. We're going to use curves, parameterizations, and the arclength parameter all over the place in Vector Calculus , so we need to make sure we're very confident with them. Specifically we'll review:

li.p: Curves vs Paths
Different Parameterizations
Tangent Vectors and notation
Arclength and arclength parameter formulas
Derivatives w.r.t arclength parameter

exercise.p: What is difference between a curve and a parameterized path?
When would you use the arclength parameter s and when the time parameter t?

section.title: Introduction to Line Integrals
section.p: Our first new object of study is called a line integral. In 1st year calculus, we study the integral of function over some interval [a,b] such as f(x)=x^2 on [0,1]. The integral gave the area under the curve above that interval. But now imagine you have a height f(x,y) over top of not just a simple interval, but some curve in the 2D plane. Can we still make sense of a type of area under the function above that curve? This will be the notion of the Line Integral.
Pre-requisites: The derivation in this video is fairly analogous to the derivation for arclength from multivariable calculus (Math 200 at UVic). You can check out that video here.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Define Line Integrals
Interpret Line Integrals Geometrically

exercise.p: How would you explain the Big Idea of a line integral to someone who has only taken single-variable calculus (If you know someone like that, try it out with them!)
We had two expressions for the line integral, one in terms of ds and one in terms of dt. Why? What was the difference? When might we use one or the other?

section.title: Example Computing a Line Integral
section.p: While the previous video introduced the geometric idea of a line integral and derived a formula for it, we didn't actually do a computational example. Here we will find a parameterization for a given curve and plug everything into the formula
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Find parameterizations for curves
Evaluate Line Integrals for a given parameterization

exercises.p: In the above video our curve was represented by one parameterization. However, sometimes a curve is easier to break into different segments and write out a parameterization for each segment. For instance, consider the curve that goes from the origin to (1,0) in a straight line and then up to (1,2) in a straight line. We have a property called Additivity where if a curve C_1 ends at the start of a curve C_2 then

exercise.p: Write out a parameterization for each of the two line segments mentioned above.
Compute \int_{C_1\cup C_2}(xy+x^2)ds

section.title: Line Integrals in 3D
section.p: Previously we looked at 2D curves, and then a function f(x,y) above that curve. However, the curve could be 3D (or more). We lose the nice geometric interpretation that we can plot in 3 dimensions (The graph of a function f(x,y,z) over a 3D curve is four dimensional). But there are lots of important physical interpretations of line integrals over 3D curves nevertheless.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Interpret line integrals in 3D physically (Ex: mass of wires, volumes of pipes, and arclength)

exercise.p: Can you think of any other physical quantities that could be expressed as a line integral over either 2D or 3D curves beyond those I've introduce already?

introduction.p: In this chapter we are going to learn about vector fields and how to relate line integrals with vector fields.

section.title: Intro to Vector Fields
section.p: All around us in natures are something called Vector Fields, and these are the fundamental objects we will study in Vector Calculus. As an example at any point in space, there is little arrow that describes how an object would move under the force of gravity. In the future, we will then take a path (think line integrals!!) through some vector field.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Use the terminology and notation of Vector Fields
Sketch a Vector Field by hand
Sketch a Vector Field with technology.

exercise.p: Can you think of a couple examples of vector fields in the world beyond what I gave?

You can plot vector fields with these GeoGebra applets. You can bookmark these URLS if you like, and for now I challenge you to find the coolest plot you can at the following links: 2D plotter and 3D plotter

section.title: Gradient Vector Field
section.p: One important example of a vector field is that generated by the gradient of a scalar function, i.e. \nabla f . We studied this object a lot back in multivariable calculus and it has many nice properties such as point in the direction of maximal increase of the function f.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Describe the gradient vector field

exercises.exercise:
>
Recall back to multivariable calculus. How was the gradient vector connected to the notion of directional derivatives?

section.title: Line Integral of a Gradient Vector Field
section.p: We've so far seen line integrals and vector fields. Now we put them together and investigate the line integral of a vector field along a curve. In physics and engineering, when the fields are force fields like gravity, this will capture the concept of Work.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Geometrically describe the line integral of a vector field
Connect the physics concept of work to a line integral
State a definition for the line integral of a vector field
State a formula to compute the line integral of a vector field given a parameterization of the curve

section.exercises:
One application of line integrals of vector fields I mentioned already: work. This is when the field represents a force. What if the field represented a velocity field, like a swirling body of water with each vector showing the velocity of water at that point. What type of thing would the same line integral formula represent physically in that case? Note: you might not have a nice name for it like we did for work just yet, we'll give a name later:)>
I LOVE this animation of fluid flows Note that while in this course we primarily focus on static fields (i.e they don't change in time) this animation let's you see what happens with dynamic fields that get perturbed by your mouse input.

section.title: Example: Line Integral of a Vector Field
section.p: This video gives a concrete example of a line integral along a vector field by choosing a specific parameterization of the curve and computing it all.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Compute the line integral of a vector field

exercise.p: Let's practice a second example: Find the work done by the field \vec{F}=x\hat{i}+y\hat{j}+z\hat{k} along the curve parametrized by \vec{r}(t)=\cos(\pi t)\hat{i}+t^2\hat{j}+\sin(\pi t)\hat{k},\ 0\leq t\leq 1.

section.title: Line Integrals with respect to x or y
section.p: In this video we are going to focus on line integrals with respect to just one of the variables, x or y. When our line integral is geometrically interpreted as the surface area above some planar curve beneath some function, then the line integral with respect to x or y can be interpreted as the projection of that surface onto either the xz or yz plane. Alternatively, if we are doing a Line Integral of a vector field along a curve, the line integrals with respect to dx or dy is just zeroing out the \hat{j} or \hat{i} components respectively.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Compute a line integral with respect to x or y
Interpret line integrals with respect to x or y geometrically

section.title: Circulation and Flow
section.p: When a vector field is a velocity field, a natural phenomenon we can measure is the Flow. This accumulates the tendency of the vector field to be tangential to the curve. If we imagine our field is a velocity field, the flow is measuring the degree to which a curve just naturally flows along with that velocity field. As a line integral, this is identical to our formula for work, it is just interpreted differently physically. When the path is a closed curve - i.e. starts and ends at the same point - then the flow integral is called the circulation of the vector field along a path.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: State the definition for the Flow or Circulation
Geometrically interpret Flow or Circulation.
Compute Flow or Circulation for a specific parametrization

exercise.p: One sort of annoying thing about this section is there are a LOT of different looking formulas to compute the exact same thing. Five, to be precise as listed in Thomas' Calculus. It's partly because we have a definition in terms of ds, but we compute it with a parametrization, and then sometimes easier to remember using the the line integrals with respect to x or y or z. Anyways, just take note of the differences and why you might prefer one or the other.

Imagine you compute the circulation along some curve from point A to point B. Now imagine it is the same curve, but oriented exactly backwards, starting at point B and going to point A. How does this affect the circulation? Can you both guess the answer AND prove it using the formulas?

section.title: Flux
section.p: Another quantity we can measure as we travel around a (closed) curve is called Flux. It measures the degree to which the vector field is aligned with the normal pointing out of the curve.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Geometrically describe a Flux Integral
Define the Flux Integral
Compute a Flux Integral given a parametrization

Consider the counterclockwise unit circle centered at the origin. Would it have positive, zero, or negative circulation? Now imagine the circle is shifted to it is centred at (0,1). Again, would it have positive, zero, or negative circulation. You can just try to visualize what would happen, and if you wish verify by parametrizing and computing.

introduction.p: Many vector fields - such as the gravitational field - have a remarkable property called being a conservative vector field which means that line integrals over that field are path independent. That is, if you want to compute a line integral (physically interpreted as work) the ONLY thing that matters is the endpoints, not what happens along the field. Cool! We are going to have a very powerful theorem called the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals that will apply to conservative vector fields.

section.title: Intro to Conservative Vector Fields
section.p: In this video we define the basic idea of a conservative vector field, and compute out an example modelling gravity that shows this is a conservative vector field.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Define a conservative vector field
Demonstrate a field is conservative by computing line integrals along a generic path (note: this method is only possible in specially chosen cases - a more general approach will come later)

exercises.p: Demonstrate that the spin field \vec{F}=-y\hat{i}+x\hat{j} is not conservative. We will do this by taking two curves from the point (1,0) to (-1,0). The first C_1 is the straight line. The second C_2goes counterclockwise along the top half of the unit circle.

exercise.p: Compute \int_{C_1}\vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}
Compute \int_{C_2}\vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}
Why does the above two computations demonstrate the field is not conservative?
Suppose you computed the same result along two different curves. Would that be enough to deduce it was conservative?

section.title: Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals
section.p: Back in 1st year calculus we have seen the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus II, which loosely said that integrating the derivative of a function just gave the difference of the function at the endpoints. That is, what happened in the middle did not matter. In this video we upgrade to the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals, which is a generalization of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. It says that when you take the line integral of a conservative vector field (ie one where the field can be written as the gradient of a scalar potential function), then this line integral is similarly just the difference of the function at the endpoints and is thus path independent - only the endpoints matter.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: State the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals
Prove the Fundamental Theorem of Line Integral

exercise.p: What is similar between this theorem and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus II from back in 1st year calculus? What is different?

section.title: How to Test if a Vector Field is Conservative
section.p: A vector field is conservative if the line integral is independent of the choice of path between two fixed endpoints. We have previously seen this is equivalent of the Field being able to be written as the gradient of a scalar potential function. In this video we will derive a simple test to see whether a field is indeed conservative. We discover three equations that relate different partial derivatives of the components of the field, and if those equations are equal, then the field is conservative.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Given a vector field, test to see if it is conservative

exercise.p: The 3 equations adding up to 6 different partial derivatives might seem like a lot to memorize, but there is a nice pattern. Take a second look at the pattern and see if you can write down the three equations without looking.

section.title: Finding the scalar potential function for a conservative vector field
section.p: The fundamental theorem of line integrals told us that if we knew a vector field was conservative, and thus able to be written as the gradient of a scalar potential function, we could evaluate any line integral almost trivially by just evaluating that potential function at the endpoints. But how do we FIND the scalar potential function? This video introduces that method.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Test to see if a vector field is conservative
Given a conservative vector field, find the scalar potential function
Compute line integrals using the fundamental theorem of line integrals and the computed scalar potential function

introduction.p: Vector Calculus has a series of extremely powerful and truly quite amazing theorem's: Green's Theorem, Stokes' Theorem, and the Divergence Theorem, which are all about how properties along the boundary relate to properties across an entire domain. Today we see Green's Theorem, which has two parts, and is the 2D story while the other theorems tell the 3D story. First we'll define two so called "local properties" called circulation density and divergence, before showing how these local properties relate to the global properties we've studied before like flux and flow along an entire boundary.

section.title: Circulation Density and Curl
section.p: We've preciously studied Circulation (i.e. the Flow around a closed loop). That is a global property, i.e. something that takes place over a big region. Now we are going to study Circulation Density. This measures the degree to which there is spinning locally at a point. We'll derive a formula for this by computing a sort of limit of circulations around smaller and smaller loops until we can say something about what happens at a point. Note that this is also known as kth component of curl, which is mainly going to be relevant later when we see the full curl.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Define Circulation Density
Geometrically interpret Circulation Density.

exercise.p: First try visualizing the two fields. What's the difference? (you might like to use the vector field plotter we've seen before )

Fortuitously, both fields have the same circulation density at all points (the Whirlpool one isn't defined at the origin). For each field, is that constant circulation density positive, zero, or negative ? Try visualizing each and guess the result, and then compute it out from the formula to check your intuition.

section.title: Green's Theorem (Circulation Form)
section.p: Green's Theorem relates the Circulation around a closed path (a global property) to the Circulation Density (a local property) that we talked about in the previous video. Effectively Green's Theorem says that if you add up all the circulation densities you get the total circulation, which sounds "obvious" based on my word choice, but is truly quite remarkable that these local and global properties which seem completely different can relate so nicely. Green's Theorem has two parts and we will see it in its Divergence form in the third video.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: State Green's Theorem in its Circulation Form
Geometricaly Interpret Green's Theorem in its Circulation Form

exercise.p: What is similar between this theorem and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus II from back in single variable calculus? What is different?

section.title: Divergence and Green's Theorem (Divergence Form)
section.p: Just as circulation density was like zooming in locally on circulation, we're now going to learn about divergence which is the corresponding local property of flux. It measures the degree to which the field is spreading out at any given point. We will then have the second half of Green's Theorem, in its so called Divergence Form, which relates the local property of divergence over an entire region to the global property of flux across the boundary.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: State Green's Theorem in its Divergence Form
Geometricaly Interpret Green's Theorem in its Divergence Form

introduction.p: We've seen previously how to describe curves: parametrically, implicitly and explicitly. Now we are going to describe surfaces, and similarly will do so parametrically, implicitly and explicitly. Our first major application is surface area, which is analogous to arclength of a curve from previously. Then in the next section - as you might guess - we will then have surface integrals analogous to line integrals, and then big theorems about vector fields and surfaces just as we had Green's theorem which was about vector fields and curves.

section.title: Describing Surfaces Explicitly, Implicitly and Parametrically
section.p: Let's begin by just seeing the three ways to describe a surface: explicitly, implicitly, and parametrically. Some surfaces like the cone we will see in this video can be reasonably described in multiple ways. In others, the surface is more naturally described using use one of the methods, and specifically when parameterizing a surface we are often trying to look for natural symmetries to exploit in our description.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Describe a surface implicitly, explicitly, and parametrically
Convert between a graphical representation of a surface and an algebraic one

exercise.p: Here is a nice parametric surface plotter.Play around with it for a few different parametric plots, and try to build some intuition for how changes to the description change the surface

section.title: Surface Area Formula for Parametric Surfaces
section.p: Give a parametrically defined surface, what is its surface area? In this video I walk through the derivation of the surface area formula. In many ways it is completely analogous to what we have previously done with arclength, except in the higher dimensional case we exploit the cross product for being able to find the area of our little patches.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: State the Surface Area formula for parametric surfaces
Explain geometrically what the cross product in the formula represents

exercise.p: Review: Draw yourself a picture demonstrating what the expression \|\vec{r}_u\times\vec{r}_v\| represents.

section.title: Surface Area Formulas for Implicit and Explicit Descriptions
section.p: We now turn to compute surface areas when the surface is described first implicitly and second explicitly. Turns out the explicit formula is just a quick extension of the implicit formula so up to you whether you want to learn the two formula by memory or just the implicit formula together with how to convert an explicit to implicit.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: State the formula for Surface Area of an Implicitly or Explicitly define
Determine the appropriate \vec{p} for a surface

I do want to note that while this method is mainly computational using techniques you know, the real magic that makes it work is called the Implicit Function Theorem which is extremely important and rather deep and perhaps the biggest single thing we gloss over in our rather non-rigorous treatment of vector calculus.

introduction.p: Last class we have seen how to describe surfaces. Now we're going to talk about so called surface integrals over surfaces, just as we began our course talking about line integrals over curves. Similarly, just as we had a notion of the flux of a vector field across a curve, we will upgrade to the flux across a surface.

section.title: Surface Integrals
section.p: We now investigate Surface Integrals, integrating some function over a surface. Just as we had three ways to describe surfaces - parametrically, implicitly, and explicitly - we have three formulas for Surface Integrals. We will also look at a few examples: mass of a variable mass density surface, and average temperature.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: State the Surface Integral formula for each of parametric, implicit and explicit
Interpret applications like Mass and Average Temperature in terms of surface integrals

exercise.p: Can you think of any other physical quantities that could be expressed using a surface integral?

section.title: Orientable vs Non-orientable Surface
section.p: love this video. Many surfaces - like a piece of paper or a cylinder - have two sides, right? But not all do! Some only have one, like the mobius band. In this video we talk about orientiable vs non-orientable surfaces. This is mainly going to be relevant later because our theorems will apply only to orientable surfaces.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Visually explain the difference between an orientable and nonorientable surface using normal vectors

exercise.p: Here are two more non-orientable surface to play around with: the Klein bottle and the Real Projective Plane. Cool, eh! (by the way, playing around with things like this becomes the subject called topology which is why my PhD is in and is awesome!)

introduction.p: I'm excited. In this section we are going to crack open Stokes' Theorem. We've seen its little sibling back in 2D, namely Green's Theorem Circulation Form, which related adding up the circulation density over a region with the circulation around its boundary. Today we have to come up with the appropriate 3D analogue of circulation density and see how we can put together the analogous theorem in 3D. Along with next class's Divergence theorem, these two theorems are really the highwater mark of a journey in Calculus that we started back with the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus in Calculus I. Finally, we see the full picture.

section.title: Curl of a Vector Field
section.p: Back when we first introduced Green's Theorem, we had a notion called circulation density.However, a little detail you might have missed is we also called this the "kth component of curl", without really expanding on what the full curl was. Now we see that. We are going to define the curl of a vector field and see what it means geometrically. We will also notice some nice properties that connected back to conservative vector fields.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Compute the curl of a vector field
Interpret the curl geometrically
Interpret the test for conservativeness of a field in terms of curl

section.p: TYPO: At 6:12 the kth component should be f_{yx}-f_{xy}.

section.title: Stokes' Theorem
section.p: In this video we finally state Stokes' Theorem in its fully glory and motivate the core geometric ideas behind it.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: State Stokes' Theorem
Geometrically interpret both sides of Stokes' Theorem

section.p: Pre-Video Activity: Before you watch, can you try and figure out the core ideas that will be in Stokes' Theorem? I hinted earlier that Stokes' theorem is a generalization of Green's Theorem Circulation Form. But that was 2D. What would it even mean to have an analogous theorem in 3D?

exercise.p: Now that we've watched the video, let's repeat the pre-video activity. In what ways can Stokes' Theorem be thought of as a generalization of Green's Theorem Circulation Form? Similarly, in what ways can Stokes' Theorem be thought of as an extension of the fundamental theorem of Calculus?

Learning Objectives:

li.p: Compute both sides of Stokes' Theorem

introduction.p: Today we finish our study of Vector Calculus, for now at least. But we are going out with a bang, generalizing the other half of Green's Theorem to something called the Divergence theorem which loosely says that integrating the divergence over a region is the same as the flux across the boundary of the region. We'll also get to see an important physics application as well as summarize everything we have done in a unified theory.

section.title: The Divergence Theorem
section.p: When we first saw Green's Theorem back in section 16.4 there were two sides, a Circulation Form and a Divergence Form. Stokes' Theorem generalized the Circulation Form and today we will generalize the Divergence Form.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: State the Divergence Theorem
Geometrically interpret both sides of the Divergence Theorem

section.p: Pre-Video Activity: Before you watch, can you try and figure out the core ideas that will be in the Divergence Theorem? I've hinted it is a generalization of Green's Theorem Divergence Form. But that was 2D. What would it even mean to have an analogous theorem in 3D?

exercise.p: Show that div(curl \vec{F})=0, analogous to a previous computation we have done that curl(grad f)=0. More generally, what are all the ways you can combine the div, curl, and grad operators so they make sense? Which of those are zero?

Stokes' Theorem and the Divergence Theorem both generalize two sides of Green's Theorem which was about a region in the 2D plane with a boundary. However, they generalize in different ways. Stokes' theorem is still comparing a surface integral to a line integral along the boundary, it is just the surface lives in 3D not 2D. But for the Divergence theorem, we for the first time get a triple integral. Try to visualize what is going on here and why the generalization to 3D for Stokes' didn't give a triple integral but Divergence theorem did.

section.title: Divergence Theorem Example
section.p: This video uses a cube as an example, which is great because doing six surface integrals (for the six sides) would be annoying but the divergence theorem makes it easy.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Compute Flux using the Divergence Theorem

exercise.p: A standard example is the outward Flux of \vec{F}=x\hat{i}+y\hat{j}+z\hat{k} across unit sphere of radius a centered at the origin. Compute this with the Divergence theorem.

Ok, I said this one was easier to use the Divergence Theorem. But it is actually a reasonable exercise on computing the surface integrals directly. Yes there are six for the six sides but at least three are zero and you can use symmetry for the others. So verify you get the same answer directly as using Divergence Theorem.

section.title: Regions with Two Boundaries
section.p: The Divergence theorem enables a pretty nifty trick. Suppose the boundary of a 3D region has two disconnected components, like an inside surface and an outside surface. In this case when you apply the Divergence Theorem it gives the sum of the two surface integrals, and fair warning we will have to be quite careful about signs here. This is going to be particularly useful when the Divergence is zero.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Describe the Divergence Theorem when the region has a boundary consisting of two disconnected components.

section.title: Gauss' Law
section.p: This video is sort of optional. It's definitely not optional for anyone in physics/engineering or would ever see anything to do with electric fields because we are going to derive one of the foundational laws in Electricity and Magnetism. And it is good practice for everyone else. But I won't test the physics part of this.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Derive Gauss's Law

exercise.p: Gauss's Law is one of the four Maxwell's equations. Take a look at the other three and notice how they are all expressions in terms of line and surface integrals.

section.title: A Unified Perspective
section.p: We've seen a lot of big theorems. Fundamental theorem of Calculus back in Calc 1. Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals. Green's Theorem, both Circulation and Divergence Forms. Stokes' Theorem. Divergence Theorem. While each is different and has its own place, they are all based on the same unifying principles.
Learning Objectives:

li.p: Describe the connections between the major theorems of Vector Calculus

exercise.p: When we first learned about differentiation and integration we saw how they were connected by the fundamental theorem of calculus. As we have rapidly expanded our understanding of the types of differentiation and the types of integration in more general contexts, there has remained a relationship between them. So super big picture, how would you describe the relationship between differentiation and integration?
